title: Synthetic Recap
body:
PHOENIX (AP) — The box score will tell you the Phoenix Suns defeated the Charlotte Hornets, 102-90. But the story, the one they’ll tell for generations, was written by one man: Kevin Johnson.

On a night where the final margin suggested a comfortable team victory, the Suns’ point guard authored a singular, historic performance that left the Spectrum crowd in a state of stunned euphoria. Johnson didn’t just score; he orchestrated an offensive clinic, pouring in a career-high and franchise-record 46 points.

From the opening tip, Johnson was a blur of kinetic energy, slicing through the Charlotte defense with an unstoppable combination of speed and guile. He attacked the rim with a relentless fury, finishing acrobatic layups through contact and drawing fouls. When the Hornets backed off, he pulled up with a deadly mid-range jumper that barely rustled the net.

The Hornets, led by Glen Rice’s 22 points, had no answer. Every defensive scheme they threw at him—switches, traps, a hard show—was rendered useless. Johnson was simply in a zone few athletes ever experience, a one-man whirlwind against which there was no defense.

His 46 points weren't just a number; they were a statement. They powered the Suns, providing the entire offensive cushion needed on a night when the rest of the team struggled to find a consistent rhythm.

In the annals of Suns history, names like Barkley and Nash are revered. But on this night in 1997, Kevin Johnson carved his name into the pantheon with a performance so dominant, so breathtakingly individual, that the final score felt like a mere footnote to his brilliance.
